content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Interesting problem. I like the fact that a little bit of optimisation is required for the code to work.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: The fact that gcd(a,a+1)==1 is probably not obvious, but one can write naive solution and exit in case of current gcd == 1, so I don’t see any problems
I hope you received enough feedback from the community to improve your contribution. Once you have made the necessary updates, publish your contribution!

I like the idea, and have upvoted. I would rewrite the problem statement to be more clear and grammatically correct. As of now, I see the following possible corrections:

1. You'll receive an array in a non usual way. Instead of giving the array itself, it will be N ranges. -----> You'll be given an array in the form of `N` ranges. 

2. Each range is defined by two integers Li and Ri, and it means that contains all numbers ranging from Li to Ri, inclusive. -----> Each range is defined by two integers `L_i` and `R_i` and contains all numbers from L_i to R_i, inclusive.

3. For example, the ranges 3..5 and 4..6, represents the array [3,4,5,4,5,6].
------>  For example, the ranges 3..5 and 4..6, represent the array [3,4,5,4,5,6].

4. I would change `Li` and `Ri` to `L_i` and `R_i`  in the problem statement just for clarity.

5. 
Output
Line 1: An integer GCD, the greatest common divisor of the array.  ----->


Output
Line 1: One integer GCD, the greatest common divisor of the array.




Notice the grammar changes.

I enjoyed the challenge of the unique way of specifying ranges, that made me think.

A pretty straightforward solution exists by brute force but in my IDE is stalled out for Test 4 - probably because it was a big number - and I see that could be a critical part of the challenge.

But at that point the leap to the insight about how to find a gcd you way evaded me, and I was stuck in a rabbit hole of trying to optimise what I had without any inkling there might be a clever way (a problem of 'you dont know what you dont know') So I probably wouldn't have searched for a mathematical shortcut online.

I probably would have got frustrated if I were doing this, and not enjoyed it - but only because of the Test 4 challenge

Thanks for your review.
Well, actually i dont know why i did that way, but it works using g = 1LL too.
I think in order to solve this problem fast, you need to know the property that every two consecutives numbers are coprimes with each other, otherwise you'll have to figure out using the test cases.

thanks for your review.
The simple brute force solution is not supposed to be accepted, the main trick on this problem is to know that every consecutive numbers are coprime with each other, so any range that contains more than one element the gcd is equal one, and the gcd of the array is equal of the gcd's of the ranges.

Yeah, I was wondering it could have some grammar errors (not that english specialist hehe), thanks, I accepted almost every change you suggested, just the `L_i` and `R_i` for personal reasons, I prefer the another way, hope you dont mind.

Well, the fact that gcd(a, a+1) = 1 is not difficult to see if we know a little bit of number theory. Since gcd(a, b) = gcd(a, b−a) whenever a < b, we have that gcd(a, a+1) = gcd(a, a+1−a) = gcd(a, 1) = 1.

sure

oh, one more thing:

I would use scientific notation for constraints: e.g. 1e15 instead of 1000000000000000
